titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Ruth St. Denis Papers LSC.1031
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Zoe Macleod, 2012-2014 and Carolina Meneses, 2018; machine-readable finding aid created by Caroline Cubé.

p.date: Online finding aid last updated 2025 June 10.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

publicationstmt.p: Finding aid description and metadata in this record are licensed under a Creative Commons Public Domain Designation (CC0 1.0 Universal). See LSC's Metadata Rights Statement for more information.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2025-08-25 14:17:59 -0700.

did.abstract: Ruth St. Denis (1879-1968) was a modern dance pioneer who combined spirituality and dance. Throughout her career, St. Denis's dances were greatly influenced by eastern culture and religion. In the later years of her career, Christian themes were also explored and depicted in her works. Her papers include handwritten journals, personal and professional correspondence, essays, poems, lectures, choreographic notes, musical scores, dance programs and ephemera, photographic prints, reel-to-reel audio recordings, books from her personal library, and business materials. The collection spans the majority of her life, though the bulk of collection derives from the 1920s to her death in 1968.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
Seven envelopes of negatives in Box 153, Folder 11 unvailable due to damaged condition.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of Item], Ruth St. Denis Papers (Collection 1031). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Initial processing of this collection was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, and administered by the Council on Library and Information Resources (CLIR), Cataloging Hidden Special Collections and Archives program.
Further processing by Zoe Macleod with assistance from Jillian Cuellar in the Center for Primary Research and Training (CFPRT), 2012-2014.
Revision of description in subseries 2.3 by Carolina Meneses with assistance from Jasmine Jones in the Center for Primary Research and Training (CFPRT), 2018.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Ruth St. Denis (1879-1968) was a modern dance pioneer who combined spirituality and dance. Throughout her career, St. Denis's dances were greatly influenced by eastern culture and religion. In the later years of her career, Christian themes were also explored and depicted in her works. Born Ruth Dennis in New Jersey, she later added "St." as part of her stage name. St. Denis's training began as a child, with the practice of physical exercises developed by François Delsarte. This greatly influenced her future style of dance. As a teenager, she appeared in Broadway musicals and was a protégé of David Belasco. Inspired by a poster advertising Egyptian Deities Cigarettes with an image of the Egyptian goddess Iris, St. Denis began choreographing dances that expressed the goddess's mysticism. The first dance piece that brought her into the circuit of higher art was Radha, which she first performed in 1906. This dance portrayed the story of Krishna and his love for a mortal maid. St. Denis's intention was to create a work that would serve as a spiritual expression of eastern cultural themes.

In 1914, St. Denis married her dance partner, Ted Shawn. The following year, they founded the Denishawn School of Dance in Los Angeles, California, one of the first schools devoted to "aesthetic dancing." In 1920, the school moved to New York City. Aesthetic dancing involved spiritual, natural movements. Some of Denishawn's illustrious pupils were Martha Graham, Doris Humphrey, Charles Weidman, and Louise Brooks, the future film star. The Denishawn dancers toured Asia for fifteen months in 1925, performing dances inspired by Asian and Egyptian cultures.

In 1927, St. Denis founded the Society of Spiritual Arts, focusing on the religious aspects of dance. In 1931, St. Denis and Shawn separated maritally, but did not legally divorce. Though they dissolved Denishawn, St. Denis remained close to Shawn throughout her career. In 1934, St. Denis founded the Church of Divine Dance at her studio in Los Angeles, which, like the Society of Spiritual Arts, established dance as a means of worship. Here, she led dance masses and rituals. In 1938, she founded the first college dance program in an American university at Adelphi University in New York State.

St. Denis died of a heart attack in Hollywood, California in 1968. As a pivotal figure of modern dance, she left behind an esteemed legacy and several dance companies have honored her by performing her pieces. She was inducted into the National Museum of Dance's Mr. & Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney Hall of Fame in 1987, and was among the first to be distinguished by the Dance Heritage Coalition in its America's Irreplaceable Dance Treasures http://www.danceheritage.org/treasures.html.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection is comprised of the personal papers of Ruth St. Denis. It includes St. Denis's handwritten journals, which begin at the turn of the century and continue until weeks before her death, personal and professional correspondence, essays, poems, lectures, choreographic notes, musical scores, dance programs and ephemera, photographic prints, reel-to-reel audio recordings, books from her personal library, and business materials. The collection spans the majority of her life, though the bulk of collection derives from the 1920s to her death in 1968.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Reflections on a life in the dance. Ruth St. Denis, interviewee. UCLA Oral History Department interview, 1965. UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Elyse Robert collection on Ruth St. Denis, 1932-1991 (Collection 1735). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Ruth St. Denis Collection. Adelphi University Archives and Special Collections, Garden City, NY.
Photograph Collection on Ruth St. Denis. MS-P070. Special Collections and Archives, The UC Irvine Libraries, Irvine, California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The journals series contains bound journals and loose journal entries that were written throughout St. Denis's life, from the early 1900s to 1968 a few weeks before she passed away. These journals include such topics as St. Denis' performances, choreographic concepts, religious and aesthetic views, community and social problems, travels, personal life, and public image as an artist. Her journals provide insight into the struggles she faced towards the end of her career when St. Denis did not have the financial stability to perform what she wanted and as often as she wanted.

did.physdesc: Folder contains a bound leather notebook in delicate condition, handle with care.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence and references to Light of Asia and the Divine Dance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The correspondence series contains letters written from the 1890s and 1968 between St. Denis and friends, family, business partners, members of her studio, and students. Some of the letters St. Denis sent were newsletters she sent to her friends and family to keep them up to date on her life. This series also contains greeting cards sent to St. Denis from friends, family, and students, as well as contact lists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Consists of lists of contact information for St. Denis's colleagues, students, and members of St. Denis's various organizations.

did.unittitle: Contact lists for Society of Spiritual Arts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Consists of greeting cards sent to St. Denis, mainly around Christmas or her birthday. The cards are mainly from her friends and family, as well as many of her students.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Consists of letters written to and from St. Denis and Ted Shawn, Pearl Wheeler, William Skipper, as well as her students, members of her organizations, and business associates. These letters discuss such topics as performances, choreography, travel, personal, fundraising, and other business matters.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Carolina Meneses revised description for correspondence in this series to ensure consistency in description and provide better discovery and access points. Titles were at times ambiguous and misleading to users. For instance, some of the original titles included the term "history letter" and after some research, Meneses determined that these were long letters that St. Denis wrote to her friends and colleagues to keep them up to date with her life. The New York Public Library's Jerome Robbins Dance Division also has history letters in their collection of Ruth St. Denis papers.

Since files contained letters between St. Denis and diverse people discussing a variety of topics, and dates were the most common thread, Meneses decided to preference the dates over devising new, more comprehensive titles. She provided a scope and content note for each file and documented the primary creators in the letters in the files' descriptions. Primary creators were designated as those represented in the majority of the materials in the files or have a significant relationship with St. Denis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten letters primarily between Ruth, her mother Ruth Emma Hull Dennis, and her father Thomas Laban Denis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Compilation of letters by Ruth to her parents Ruth Emma Hull Dennis and Thomas Laban Denis. Letters primarily sent during her trip to London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten letters by Ruth to her parents Ruth Emma Hull Dennis and Thomas Laban Denis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten letters primarily between Ruth, her mother Ruth Emma Hull Dennis, her father Thomas Laban Denis, and her brother Buzz Dennis, also known as Brother St. Denis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Handwritten letters primarily between Ruth, her mother Ruth Emma Hull Dennis, her father Thomas Laban Denis, and her brother Buzz Dennis, also known as Brother St. Denis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten letters primarily between Ruth's mother Ruth Emma Hull Dennis, and her father Thomas Laban Dennis while they resided at Bishops Sanitarium in Pasadena and the Soldier's Home in Sawtelle, respectively. Also letters between Ruth, her mother and father, as well as correspondence between her father and his friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily letters to Ruth from dance companies, theaters, schools, and other arts organizations regarding performances, appearances, and dances.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily letters, sympathy cards, and telegrams regarding the death of Ruth's mother, Ruth Emma Hull Dennis. Some letters from Buzz Dennis, Ted Shawn, newspaper clippings and obituaries, as well as photos of Ruth's mother. Letters to Thomas Laban Denis regarding his Civil War pensions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily correspondence between Ruth and Pearl Wheeler.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mostly letters between Ruth and diverse people and organizations, discussing a variety of topics. Some correspondence between Ruth and Ted Shawn. Includes some writings and "history letters" by Ruth that she sent to various people to keep them up to date with her plans and activities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily letters and telegrams regarding the death of Ruth's mother, Ruth Emma Hull Dennis. Some letters between Ruth and her brother, Buzz Dennis (also known as Brother St. Denis).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters to Ruth from Brother Don, Krishna Lal Shridharani, and Kendall K. Mussey. Also includes a program by the Hindustan Association of America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters from Ruth to various figures inviting them for tea to discuss an upcoming Moral Re-Armament meeting. Recipients include Martha Graham, Helen Hayes, Fredric March, Katherine Hepburn among others. Only includes responses from some.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily letters between Ruth and various people and organizations, including Pearl Wheeler, Ted Shawn, Brother St. Denis and "Wilson". Personal and fan letters written to Ruth. Contracts for appearances and engagements under her agent, Edward W. Lowrey. Letters from Ruth's secretary to potential sponsors for the Chicago World's Fair. Solicitations sent out to colleges regarding dance performances.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mostly letters between Ruth and diverse people and organizations, discussing a variety of topics. Also includes writings by Ruth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One letter to Ruth from Ted Shawn where he goes into detail about a difficult summer and his plans during his upcoming travels to New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily letters between Ruth and various people and organizations, including Ted Shawn and Brother St. Denis. Includes some writing by Ruth, as well as "history letters" which she wrote to various colleagues and friends to keep them up to date with her plans and activities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily handwritten letters to Ruth from Ida Marshall.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters from Mildred Rice of the Ruth St. Denis Studio to Mr. Robert Saudek of the Ford Foundation, Ed Sullivan of Toast of the Town, and Dodd Mead & Co. Publishers regarding Ruth's availability for appearances on television.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily letters between Ruth and various people and organizations, including Ted Shawn, William Skipper, Harro Meller, Brother St. Denis (also known as Buzz), DANCE Magazine, and Adelphi College. Some letters were sent by Aubrey St. John on behalf of Ruth. Also writings by Ruth, including "history letters" that she sent to various people to keep them up to date with her plans and activities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily letters and greeting cards between Ruth and a variety of people and organizations, including William Skipper, Harro Meller, and Arthur Todd.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters to Ruth from fans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from Arthur Todd to William Schuman. Postcards to Ruth from friends, as well as an invitation from Adelphi College. Letters between Ruth and Alfred Frantz Stury and John Dougherty of the Ruth St. Denis Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mostly correspondence between Ruth and Alfred Frantz Stury, director of the Ruth St. Denis Center. Some letters between Ruth's secretary, Bernice Andres and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily letters to Ruth from various people and organizations, including Ted Shawn. Some correspondence between Ruth St. Denis Center (Ruth, Alfred Frantz Stury or a secretary) and Klarna Pinska.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mostly correspondence between the Ruth St. Denis Center (to or by Ruth, Alfred Frantz Stury, or a secretary) and Klarna Pinska.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily letters to Ruth by diverse people and organizations, discussing a variety of topics. Includes some black and white photographs of Ruth, as well as her writings. Some letters undated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily letters and greeting cards between Ruth and a variety of people and organizations, including William Skipper, Ted Shawn, Aubrey St. John, Adelphi College, and Drake University. Also letters between Alfred B. Stury and a variety of entities on behalf of Ruth as director of the Ruth St. Denis Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily letters between Ruth and diverse people and organizations, discussing a variety of topics. Correspondents include Ted Shawn, William Skipper, Harro Meller, Brother St. Denis (also known as Buzz), Adelphi College, UCLA, John Dougherty, and Klarna Pinska. Several letters from the director of the Ruth St. Denis Center, Alfred Frantz Stury, to various entities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mostly writings by Ruth, including "history letters" that she sent to various people to keep them up to date with her plans and activities. Some correspondence between members of the Ruth St. Denis Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily letters between the director of the Ruth St. Denis Center, Alfred B. Stury and a variety of entities. Some correspondence between Ruth and William Skipper, Aubrey St. John of Adelphi College, and Ted Shawn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily letters between the director of the Ruth St. Denis Center, Alfred B. Stury and a variety of entities. Some correspondence between Ruth and William Skipper, Aubrey St. John of Adelphi College, Drake University, and John Dougherty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mostly correspondence between Alfred Frantz Stury and a variety of entities on behalf of Ruth as director of the Ruth St. Denis Center. Includes letters to and by the American Guild of Musical Artists and the Canadian Broadcasting Corporations. Also letters between the Ruth St. Denis Center and Barbara Andres from Adelphi College.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Primarily letters between Ruth and various people and organizations, including William Skipper, Forrest Thornburg, and Ted Shawn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mostly letters between Ruth and diverse people and organizations, discussing a variety of topics. Correspondents include William Skipper and Aubrey St. John. Includes some writings and "history letters" by Ruth that she sent to various people to keep them up to date with her plans and activities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One letter by Alfred Frantz Stury, director of the Ruth St. Denis Center regarding "Ruth St. Denis Lecture Films."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mostly letters between Ruth and diverse people and organizations, discussing a variety of topics. Also includes writings by Ruth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The writings series contains essays and manuscripts of St. Denis's autobiography, An Unfinished Life; poems; and lectures and speeches written by St. Denis, Ted Shawn, and other associates. Much of this material focuses on expressing spirituality through dance. St. Denis also examined the ways in which dancing and movement can enhance lives on an individual and national basis. There are multiple drafts of some essays and manuscripts, including St. Denis's autobiography, that provide insight into St. Denis's writing process. This series also contains inventories of St. Denis's writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains multiple copies of the manuscript for Ruth St. Denis's autobiography, An Unfinished Life, and Ted Shawn's book about St. Denis, Pioneer and Prophet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes "Wisdom Comes Dancing" and "Current Biography."

scopecontent.p: Includes "What is the Religious Dance?," "Current Biography," "Lecture for Connecticut College," "Traditional and Metaphysical Forms of Religious Dance," and journals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes "Rhythms on the Mound," "Intercourse Ultimates," "Woman Speaks," and handwritten, hand-bound notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes handwritten notes for "Science of Man" and "Rhythms for Traditional Worship in Christian Church."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes writings about balanced government, "Rhythms of the Resurrection," "The Church" handwritten notes, and "Inferno."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes biographical writings including notes for "An Unfinished Life," "Dialogue for a Temple," and miscellaneous writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content

scopecontent.p: Contains essays, poems, and publications written by Ted Shawn, William Skipper, other members of St. Denis's company, and other dancers, as well as a published copy of Ted Shawn's book about St. Denis, Pioneer and Prophet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains lists of St. Denis's essays and poems.

did.unittitle: Inventories of poems and speeches and lectures

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials for choreography and performance notes for many of St. Denis's dances from the second half of her career. This includes dance dramas; performance sketches and artwork; sketches of costumes and stage designs; program schedules; "Oriental dance" materials; performance research and resources; education and dance center materials that relate to the Denishawn School, School of Divine Dance, Society of Spiritual Arts Church, Creative Arts Colony, Temple materials, and Rhythmic Choir; and sheet music. These materials provide insight into how St. Denis developed her dances and the methods she use to communicate ideas to her students.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains materials for dance dramas, performances sketches and artwork depicting costumes and set designs, program schedules, and "Oriental dance" materials from the Denishawn Dancers' tour of Asia.

did.unittitle: Ballets by Ruth St. Denis, from years 1904-1930
"The Seven Purposes of the 'Friends of the Dance' Inc."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains text and images about eastern cultures, particularly Indian culture, that S. Denis used for research when developing new dances. The majority of the materials are magazine clippings.

did.unittitle: Costume, set, and prop design drawings
Subseries 4.3: Education and dance center materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains programs, flyers, and administrative records related to the Denishawn School and School of Divine Dance, Society of Spiritual Arts Church, Creative Arts Colony, Temple materials, Rhythmic Choir, and teaching materials St. Denis used for her classes.

did.unittitle: Ruth St. Denis and her Rhythmic choir

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains sheet music, some of which are annotated with dance notations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The media series contains photographs, negatives, glass negatives, photographic printing plates, and reel-to-reel tapes. Materials span from the 1880s to 1968 and document many of St. Denis's dances and live performances, publicity photos, her travels, the Denishawn dancers, her students, and her personal life.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: The majority of the materials are arranged in chronological order, expect those that are arranged in alphabetical order according to dance title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains photographs from the 1890s to 1968 that document St. Denis's personal life, travels, dances, Denishawn dancers, publicity photos, live performances, and events.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The reel-to-reel tapes are recordings of St. Denis reading her autobiography.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Audio reel to reels must be digitized prior to use.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains clippings about St. Denis and from dance publications. There are also flyers and programs from her performances, pamphlets and advertisements about St. Denis's organizations, and invitations and membership information about those organizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains newspaper and magazine clippings about St. Denis, as well as dance publications. Also includes scrapbooks of newspaper clippings.

did.unittitle: "How Beautiful upon the Mountain: A History of Jacob's Pillow" by Ted Shawn
Newspaper article on Ruth St. Denis
"The Dance: Magazine of Stage and Screen"
Creative Dance Journal: Creative Dance News of the West
"100 American Women of Accomplishment, Harper's Bazaar 1967"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains flyers, programs and advertisements from performances by St. Denis, as well as other dancers; pamphlets for dance programs and classes; and invitations to join St. Denis's organization, such as the Society of the Spiritual Arts and the Church of Divine Dance, and membership information about these organizations.

did.unittitle: Theater Intime Programs collected by Dorothy Lee Tifal
Scrapbook of Society of Spiritual Arts Church materials
"The Golden Book of Ruth St. Denis and Ted Shawn"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains books from St. Denis's personal library, the majority of which focus on religion and spirituality. This series also includes some books written by St. Denis, as well as many books written by Mary Baker Eddy. St. Denis was very influenced by Mary Baker Eddy's writings, particularly in her belief that dance was both art and religion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains financial, medical and legal materials, inventories of St. Denis's possessions, and business notes and memos pertaining to performances, St. Denis's schedule, fundraising, contracts, and St. Denis's bequest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes bank statements, receipts, and fund raising materials.

did.unittitle: Financial materials: Receipts, Denishawn House fundraising letter

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains medical records, recommendations from doctors, and dietary recommendations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes contracts and St. Denis's bequests.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes memos and meeting notes related to St. Denis's schedule and performances.

scopecontent.p: Includes inventories of St. Denis's possessions.
